author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Idaho Lawmaker Accused of Raping an Intern Resigns
description: Aaron von Ehlinger, a Republican state representative from Lewiston, has denied sexually assaulting a 19-year-old woman after the two had dinner in March.
content: An Idaho lawmaker who the police say is the focus of a criminal investigation into allegations that he raped a 19-year-old female legislative intern last month resigned on Thursday — the same day that an ethics committee recommended that he be suspended.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vaccine Fan Fiction, Boom Time for America’s Forests and Political Apathy in N.Y.C.: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote the stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Brown, Sindhu Gnanasambandan, Soraya Shockley, Liz O. Baylen, Lisa Tobin, Tamir Kalifa and Lauren Jackson
title: Odessa, Part 4: Wellness Check
description: A mental health crisis has set in at Odessa High School and some students struggle to envision a world beyond the pandemic. But for one night, the marching band tried to forget about the coronavirus.
content: This episode contains references to mental health challenges, including eating disorders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charise Mericle Harper
title: It’s a Dog’s Life — or Is It?
description: In Remy Lai’s graphic novel, “Pawcasso,” a dog that crashes an art class may not be who he seems.
content: PAWCASSOBy Remy Lai
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Where Is the New York Mayor’s Race Headed?
description: Andrew Yang is leading. Scott Stringer is under a cloud. Their rivals are jostling for a boost of momentum.
content: With less than two months to go until the all-important Democratic primary, the New York City mayor’s race is one of the costliest and most closely watched political campaigns in the country this year. It’s also one of the most uncertain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report first quarterly profits after several losses.
description: Oil prices have climbed in recent months and are now roughly where they were before the pandemic’s full force was felt.
content: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two biggest oil companies in the United States, on Friday reported their first quarterly profits after several quarters of losses, signaling that the energy industry is rebounding from the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Marc Santora
title: In Israel, dozens die in a stampede at a mass religious gathering held despite Covid warnings.
description: Israelis mourned on Friday the loss of life when a joyous pilgrimage that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews abruptly turned into a tragedy. And although the country was largely united in grief and shock, questions immediately arose about poor planning and possible negligence.
content: Israelis mourned on Friday the loss of life when a joyous pilgrimage that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews abruptly turned into a tragedy. And although the country was largely united in grief and shock, questions immediately arose about poor planning and possible negligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Bust of Elie Wiesel Is Added to Washington National Cathedral
description: The stone carving of the Holocaust survivor and author took two years to create and is the first modern-day Jewish representation in the cathedral.
content: In the western section of the Washington National Cathedral, cathedral leaders have long commemorated human rights figures. Stone carvings of Rosa Parks, Mother Teresa and other celebrated leaders grace the walls of the so-called “human rights porch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Police Find More Than 90 People Crammed Into a Houston Home
description: Houston police officers found more than 90 people — some showing symptoms of Covid-19 — “all huddled together” on Friday in what they believe may be a case of human smuggling.
content: Officers found more than 90 people crammed into a Houston home on Friday, some of them showing symptoms of Covid-19, in what was being investigated as a possible case of human smuggling, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: The Giants Traded Back and, Some Say, Well
description: Some fans scratched their heads at Dave Gettleman’s decision to trade back in the draft for the first time. But scooping receiver Kadarius Toney at No. 20 and getting draft assets was no fleecing.
content: When the Giants finally chose Kadarius Toney, a wide receiver from the University of Florida, with the 20th pick in the N.F.L. draft, the team’s fans in Cleveland took a good 10 seconds to start a slow clap, mouthing undecipherable questions beneath their masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Sentilles
title: ‘How’s Our Girl?’: On Loving a Foster Child and Letting Go
description: Every time we choose to love other mortal beings, someday, we will have to give them back.
content: “Cute baby,” strangers said when they saw her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Dan Higgins
title: Harvey Weinstein to Face Charges in Los Angeles as Early as May
description: The producer faces more than a dozen counts of sexual assault involving five different women.
content: For a year, Harvey Weinstein has been fighting attempts to extradite him from a prison near Buffalo, N.Y., to Los Angeles, a city where he was once feted as a visionary film producer and now faces multiple charges of rape and sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Zuckerman
title: How to Beat Burnout — Without Quitting Your Job
description: We’re all feeling a little fried at work and home. But there are ways to stay sharp and recharge.
content: Raise your hand if you’re completely burned out. Your inbox is an overflowing bucket of urgent requests. You are consistently asked to do more with less. Your mind is constantly reshuffling priorities, perpetually calculating the number of minutes left in the day and whether you will have enough time to finish all of your work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in May
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks from May’s new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nguyễn Phan Quế Mai
title: America, Please Don’t Forget the Victims of Agent Orange
description: Victims in Southeast Asia have never received compensation from the chemical giants that supplied herbicides during the Vietnam War.
content: Forty-six years have passed since the Vietnam War ended on April 30, 1975. While some Americans may prefer to forget its atrocities, and Vietnam is focused on forgiveness and the future, the wounds of Agent Orange victims still demand attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I Went Braless During Lockdown. What Do I Do Now?
description: A reader wonders what to wear back in the real world.
content: One of the meta questions of the moment, as we emerge from the pandemic, in-person work restarts and restaurants and entertainment sites open up, is what, of all the changes that occurred during these long periods of isolation, will stick?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: These new movies offer scares from around the world, including an Indonesian witch and an Irish vampire.
content: These new horror movies offer scares from a global perspective, including an Indonesian witch, an Irish vampire, Canadian home invaders and an American family nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: When the Goals Come Out of Nowhere
description: A Greek striker is one of the top scorers in Europe, and his play has caught the eye of big clubs. But are his goals a product of his talent, or his environment?
content: Giorgos Giakoumakis had never scored goals. Not in great numbers, anyway. He had played 22 games, spread across three seasons, before he finally managed a single one for his first club, a team of modest ambitions and close horizons called Platanias, based on his home island, Crete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Jack Ewing
title: Hurt by Losses, Credit Suisse Faces Reckoning Under New Chairman
description: The nearly $5 billion loss from the collapse of Archegos Capital Management was just the latest problem for Credit Suisse’s beleaguered investment bank.
content: After Credit Suisse said it had lost nearly $5 billion over soured trades that a small unit of its investment bank made with Archegos Capital Management, worried employees peppered Thomas Gottstein, the chief executive, with questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: True Romance: Janet Mock on the Final Season of ‘Pose’
description: As Mock says goodbye to the groundbreaking drama that changed her life, she is planning to make more television that shows people that they are not alone.
content: A year and a half ago, Janet Mock, a writer, director and executive producer on the FX drama “Pose,” began to plan a wedding. A big wedding. In a big ballroom. With music and flowers and a bride so heart-shatteringly beautiful that the groom would cry as soon as he glimpsed her at the top of the aisle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Can Relate to Ted Cruz
description: “Now that Joe’s president, I find it much easier to sleep, too,” Colbert joked on Thursday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Warner
title: Psychiatry Confronts Its Racist Past, and Tries to Make Amends
description: Critics say the field has a long way to go — from the lack of Black psychiatrists to the way it treats African-Americans.
content: Dr. Benjamin Rush, the 18th-century doctor who is often called the “father” of American psychiatry, held the racist belief that Black skin was the result of a mild form of leprosy. He called the condition “negritude.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Triumph’ Review: Going to the Mat
description: The film tells the story of an aspiring high school wrestler with cerebral palsy.
content: “Triumph” tells the story of Mike (RJ Mitte), a high school senior in the 1980s who aspires to join the wrestling team. Because he has cerebral palsy, even adults who admire his resolve — like Coach Warren (Terrence Howard), who teaches Mike in a phys-ed class, and Mike’s single father (Johnathon Schaech) — don’t initially believe he can do it. Directed by Brett Leonard, the film was inspired by the experiences of its screenwriter, Michael D. Coffey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: A Sidewalk Clock Standing Proudly in Queens Gets a Restoration
description: Local leaders raised the funds, but mysteriously, there was no record of what the battered timepiece looked like when it was installed more than 100 years ago.
content: On a busy strip of Jamaica Avenue in Queens, where vendors hawk cellphone cases outside shops selling off-price wigs, tattoo services and fungal-nail care, stands one of downtown Jamaica’s most dignified residents. This street-corner denizen is an ornate cast-iron sidewalk clock, more than a century old, attired with archaic formality like a proud codger who still wears his threadbare suit every day, even as the world passes him by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: ‘Amtrak became my family,’ Biden, a longtime commuter, says on the railroad’s 50th anniversary.
description: The president has been called “Amtrak Joe” because of the years he spent taking the train between Washington and Delaware.
content: For a majority of his political career, President Biden was a commuter, making the 90-minute Amtrak Metroliner trip between Washington and his home in Wilmington, Del., when the Senate was in session. There were even a few trips thrown in when he was vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: Some Statues Tell Lies. This One Tells the Truth.
description: Billy Frank Jr. changed the country for the better and won rights for Native Americans of the Pacific Northwest.
content: The United States is in a muddle over how to tell our history, stuck between an aggressive  revisionism that would leave few commemorative statues standing, and a stubborn clinging to all the founding myths, no matter how odious or inaccurate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas May
title: Rossini at the Drive-In, as San Francisco Opera Returns
description: Honks instead of applause: An open-air “Barber of Seville” brought the company back after 16 months.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — It feels almost too good to be true after a pandemic closure of Wagnerian scale: an audience watching a cast of singers enter the War Memorial Opera House here to rehearse and perform Rossini’s classic comedy “The Barber of Seville.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: After the Pandemic and Protests, a British Rapper Spotlights Black Businesses
description: Black Pound Day was created to find a sustainable way to support Black-owned businesses after the Black Lives Matter street protests faded.
content: LONDON — For Aimée Felone, whose children’s bookstore in London stocks tales with ethnically diverse characters, the Black Lives Matter protests last summer were, in a word, overwhelming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Death Is the Only Truth.’ Watching India’s Funeral Pyres Burn.
description: Graphic images of mass cremations cut through the Indian government’s wall of noise, misinformation and propaganda about its handling of the Covid-19 crisis.
content: NEW DELHI — The first 36 corpses were placed in the designated concrete cremation pits and set ablaze by 10 in the morning. After that, all the extra bodies went to the muddy parking lot, for a mass ceremony later.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Target Date for a Full Reopening in New York City

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Festino
title: He Delivered for Me
description: How my UPS man went from annoyance to emotional lifeline.
content: For the first year of our relationship, I didn’t know his name and didn’t welcome his interruptions. I felt hassled by the unexpected knock on my window, which was necessary to get my attention because my apartment lacked a doorbell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert
title: Expert Picks: Who Will Win the Kentucky Derby
description: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert weigh in on the contenders for the 147th running of the Kentucky Derby.
content: The horses for the 147th running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Think Outside the Brunch for Mother’s Day
description: You can do better than grocery store flowers and a card, can’t you?
content: When Evie Ebert had her first child five years ago, she started noticing something interesting. Every Mother’s Day, her social media feeds would be full of perfectly styled picnics and cooing captions like, “Felt so celebrated today!” But later, when she logged on to the private mom groups she was part of, the same women were telling a different story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Jorge Velandia Brings Venezuela to the Front Office
description: The Phillies’ assistant general manager is the highest-ranked executive his country has produced. He doesn’t plan to stop at assistant.
content: CLEARWATER, Fla. — Baseball is the national sport of Venezuela. The country has sent 428 players to the major leagues — a number topped only by the United States (over 17,000) and the Dominican Republic (794), according to the website Baseball-Reference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Chris Hamby
title: Shake-Up at Covid Vaccine Manufacturer That Tossed Millions of Doses
description: Emergent BioSolutions’ C.E.O. announced several executive changes but vigorously defended the company, which is on track for record revenues.
content: WASHINGTON — Executives of Emergent BioSolutions, the Covid-19 vaccine manufacturer that was forced to discard up to 15 million doses because of possible contamination, reported a shake-up in leadership on Thursday and offered the most fulsome defense yet of the company’s performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schultheis
title: A Refugee Who Fought Back Against the Hard Right
description: Alassa Mfouapon was falsely accused by a German tabloid and a far-right leader of starting a violent protest. So he sued them, and won.
content: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany — The country’s largest-circulation tabloid called him the “scandal asylum seeker” and accused him (falsely) of entering the country illegally. People hacked his social media accounts and broadcast his location and personal information. A far-right political leader decried him as the “ringleader” of a violent protest, while another even suggested people like him would be a good reason to bring back the death penalty in Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: ‘Firefighters Out There in the Snow’: Wildfires Rage Early in Parched West
description: Firefighters in New Mexico, Arizona and California are battling springtime blazes that have been fueled by a severe drought and boosted by climate change.
content: RUIDOSO, N.M. — New Mexico’s first major wildfire of the year ignited this week near a campground where visitors can hike to view hundreds of prehistoric petroglyphs. After scorching nearly 6,000 acres in a matter of days, the blaze remains only 13 percent contained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Set yourself up with a spread for the Kentucky Derby, with pimento cheese, deviled eggs and Hot Browns, to start.
content: Good morning. The Kentucky Derby is scheduled to run on Saturday, 6:57 p.m. Eastern time at Churchill Downs in Louisville. (I’m no handicapper, but you know my money’s on Soup and Sandwich!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge G. Castañeda
title: Biden Should Not Ignore Mexico’s Turn to Authoritarianism
description: The administration is working at cross purposes with its own agenda and long-term interests in human rights and democracy.
content: MEXICO CITY — There is no easy way to manage migration from Mexico and Central America. Not during times of economic downturn and especially not during a global pandemic. This is true for both Mexico and the United States. It’s true whether the American administration is a decent and progressive one like that of President Biden or a nativist and reactionary one like that of former President Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Latin America’s deepening crisis.
content: As vaccinations march on in some of the world’s wealthiest countries, the crisis across Latin America — and in South America in particular — has taken an alarming turn for the worse, potentially threatening the progress made beyond its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Renovating Your Kitchen This Summer? Proceed With Caution.
description: Supply chain problems and labor shortages have made home improvement projects even more complicated.
content: The salesman for the cabinets I was about to order stood in my kitchen a few weeks ago, looking worried. Normally, he would wait until after a contractor had gutted my kitchen to take final measurements, because these semi-custom cabinets ordinarily take three or four weeks to arrive. Now, because of pandemic-related delays, they would take 13 weeks, maybe more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Military Missteps Allowed Soldier Accused of Murder to Flee, Report Says
description: Officials believe that Specialist Aaron Robinson bludgeoned Specialist Vanessa Guillen to death. He later killed himself.
content: Army investigators detained a fellow soldier in the killing of Specialist Vanessa Guillen just hours after her remains were found, but a series of missteps allowed the soldier to flee, then fatally shoot himself, according to an Army report released on Friday that examined what went wrong in the high-profile investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Where Should You Buy Your Books?
description: Bookstore or Amazon? Curbside pickup or delivery? We answer common questions readers might have.
content: The last year has seen expanded options for buying books online, as more bookstores have developed websites, and e-commerce sites like Bookshop.org gain traction. But massive retailers like Amazon continue to dominate the bookselling business, and readers may be torn between the desire to support local bookstores and the convenience and price of online delivery giants. Here, booksellers and literary agents offer advice on how to evaluate your book buying options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cayce Clifford
title: Google’s Plan for the Future of Work: Privacy Robots and Balloon Walls
description: The company that helped popularize open office plans and lavish employee perks is trying to reinvent office spaces to cope with workplace sensibilities changed by the pandemic.
content: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Google’s first office was a cluttered Silicon Valley garage crammed with desks resting on sawhorses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Germany Sets Out Plans to Return Benin Bronzes
description: The government, regional legislators and major museums said they would make “substantial” returns of the famous West African artifacts starting next year.
content: Germany will begin returning a “substantial” number of the priceless artifacts known as the Benin Bronzes from its museums to Nigeria next year, its culture ministry said on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pence, in his first speech since leaving office, speaks fondly of Trump.
description: The former vice president credited the Trump administration with “four years of consequence, four years of results and four years of promises made and promises kept.”
content: In his first political speech since leaving office, former Vice President Mike Pence made clear that despite his grim falling out with former President Donald J. Trump, his days of trying to ingratiate himself to his former boss are far from over as he plots his political future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Fullerton
title: Frank Bowling’s New Paintings Are Family Affairs
description: With help from close relatives, the 87-year-old artist is still working, even if he doesn’t apply the paint himself.
content: LONDON — On a recent afternoon behind a scruffy door in South London, remarkable alchemical transformations were taking place under the watchful eye of the painter Frank Bowling. Wearing industrial masks, a team of assistants brushed and dolloped ammonia, gold powder, acrylic gel and water onto a dripping canvas hung onto Bowling’s studio wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: One Little Favor Before Their First Date
description: When Erik Leibovitz and Dara Silverman initially met online, he asked her to not go out with anyone else before they had the chance to meet in person.
content: Dara Silverman knew Erik Leibovitz for all of 15 minutes after connecting on J-Swipe in July 2015, when he asked a question that caught her off guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner, Eric Nagourney and Mike Ives
title: Stampede at Israel Religious Celebration Kills at Least 45
description: An estimated 100,000 people had gathered on Mount Meron to celebrate a religious holiday. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it a “terrible disaster.”
content: JERUSALEM — A stampede early Friday at a mountainside religious celebration in Israel that drew tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews left at least 45 people dead and scores more injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Sean Piccoli
title: One Dead as Car Hits Motorbike and Outdoor Dining Structure in Queens
description: The police identified Xing Long Lin, 37, as the victim who died. A woman was also injured at the restaurant, on a block in Astoria known for outdoor dining.
content: A 37-year-old man was fatally injured on Thursday evening when a car collided with his Yamaha motorbike and then crashed into an outdoor dining structure on a busy block of Astoria, Queens, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Florio and Ouisie Shapiro
title: Should Nurses Take a 30% Pay Cut When Their Patient Turns 23?
description: For the most fragile New Yorkers and those who care for them, turning 23 brings enormous consequences.
content: With one ear on the sound monitor linked to his daughter’s room, Joe Trimarchi sat at his dining room table in the Rosebank section of Staten Island. He was stuffing dozens of envelopes, hoping that one of them would land on the desk of a politician who might care. Mr. Trimarchi, 55, is a cashier in the billing department of Staten Island University Hospital, but what animates him is advocating for his daughter Alexia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Over 40 Dead in Tajik-Kyrgyz Border Clash as Death Toll Rises
description: Fighting that broke out over water rights also injured more than 200 people, government officials said.
content: MOSCOW — A border clash this week between Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan killed more than 40 people, government officials said Friday, significantly raising the death toll for an episode that began as a dispute over irrigation water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Finding Love and All Its Quirks, Even If 2,654 Miles Away
description: “Radical honesty” on Sarah Lenz’s dating profile, along with no geographical restrictions, led to Stephen Paskey road tripping for love.
content: In the summer of 2019, Stephen Paskey was on vacation, sitting in an Istanbul cafe, smoking a hookah. As much as he had hoped to meet a life partner by then, it just wasn’t happening. In a few years, he thought, he would retire and maybe move to South America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: ‘Fat Ham’ and new music.
content: Welcome. It’s getting lighter earlier here in New York, daylight overeager to begin the day, like many of us lately. It’s May 1 tomorrow, the weekend again, deep into a springtime “tinged by mourning and exhaustion,” even as it promises more opportunities to get together with people we’ve been missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Jim Tankersley
title: U.S. Moves to Restrict Travel From India as Virus Infections and Deaths Surge
description: As they discussed the decision this week, top health officials warned the White House about uncertainty over how vaccines might respond to a homegrown virus variant in India.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House, citing guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, announced Friday that it would begin restricting travel from India to the United States next week, a major new test of the Biden administration’s pandemic response.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Suk-joong Song, Who Left Riot-Torn Seoul for America, Dies at 90
description: A Korean immigrant, he opened a dry-cleaning business in Brooklyn, where he became a neighborhood institution. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: The T.S.A. extends mask mandate through mid-September.
description: The mandate was set to expire on May 11.
content: The Transportation Security Administration extended a mandate Friday that requires travelers to wear masks at airports, on airplanes and on commuter bus and rail systems, through Sept. 13. The mandate was set to expire on May 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: With Zach Wilson, the Jets hope to end their decades-long QB search.
description: The Jets used the second pick in the N.F.L. draft to select Zach Wilson from Brigham Young, hoping that their long search for a franchise quarterback is over.

content: The first round of the N.F.L. draft commands much of the attention, and rightly so.

title: A Year of Cooking With My Mother
description: I’ve eaten her food my whole life. This pandemic made me realize how much I didn’t know about her process.
content: Let the record show that I make a terrible roommate. I can still hear my mother’s voice as she encountered the sink full of dishes, the counter spilling over with spices and syrups: “I can’t live like this!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Rafkin
title: At the Final Curtain Call, a Proposal
description: Christopher Jones and Marissa Follo Perry, who met in kindergarten, became engaged onstage at the closing night of a production of “Sister Act,” which she directed.
content: When Christopher Jones met Marissa Follo Perry at a bus stop, his infatuation with her was immediate. It was a big day for them both: the first day of kindergarten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Apple’s App Store Draws E.U. Antitrust Charge
description: By forcing app developers to use its payment system and comply with other rules, regulators said, Apple broke European Union competition laws.
content: LONDON — European Union regulators on Friday accused Apple of violating antitrust laws by imposing unfair rules and fees on rival music-streaming services that depend on the App Store to reach customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Not-So-Long-Distance Relationship Is Bridged by a Proposal
description: Dr. Marianne Jacob and Andrew Shenoy kept up a “distance relationship” for three years until she moved across the Hudson River to a New York hospital.
content: New Brunswick, N.J., is fewer than 50 miles from New York City, but for Dr. Marianne Jacob and Andrew Shenoy, who were married April 17 at the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral in Lower Manhattan, even that relatively small geographical gap was sometimes difficult to bear. From 2016 to 2019, the couple dated while separated by the Hudson River and three New Jersey counties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian Politician Loses Court Fight Over Twisted Sister Song
description: Clive Palmer was ordered to pay more than $1 million for using “We’re Not Gonna Take It” in his party’s political advertising.
